intro: Gaya gaudichaudiana var. genuina, commonly known as the New Guinea impatiens, is a flowering plant native to the tropical regions of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Balsaminaceae and is characterized by its vibrant, showy flowers that come in a variety of colors. The plant is typically an annual or short-lived perennial, often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and floral arrangements. Its leaves are heart-shaped and succulent, while the flowers are borne in clusters on erect stems. The species is well adapted to warm, humid climates and thrives in partial to full sunlight.
